content: H.R. 3962, Affordable Health Care for America Act, passed by the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009, is based on H.R. 3200. The Congressional Budget Office estimates it would reduce federal deficits by $109 billion over 10 years and insure 96% of the non-elderly U.S. population by 2019. The Worker, Homeownership, and Business Assistance Act of 2009 (H.R. 3548) is projected to reduce federal deficits by $109 billion over 10 years. By 2019, it would insure 96% of the non-elderly, legally present U.S. population. The total cost of coverage provisions, including Exchange subsidies, federal Medicaid expenditures, and tax credits for small employers, would be $1.052 trillion over 10 years. However, the net cost of the coverage provisions would be $891 billion, offset by other spending changes and income tax surcharges on high-income individuals. The CBO analysis projects that the Affordable Health Care for America Act would cost $891 billion over 10 years. The bill aims to reduce the number of uninsured, restructure the private health insurance market, set minimum health benefit standards, provide financial assistance, and raise revenues. The House of Representatives passed the Affordable Health Care for America Act on November 7, 2009. The bill focuses on reducing the number of uninsured individuals, restructuring the private health insurance market, setting minimum health benefit standards, providing financial assistance, and implementing provisions to raise revenues. Key provisions include mandatory health insurance for individuals and employers, market reforms like modified community rating and guaranteed issue and renewal, and acceptable coverage under a qualified health benefits plan. It would not affect plans for specific services like dental or vision care. Revenues would be raised by limiting employer deductions for certain health insurance plans and modifying tax-advantaged accounts for health care spending.
